entries: Die Anwesenheit der Blauen Dame kann den See der Ahnen und die umliegenden Räume auf verschiedene Weise beeinflussen. Überlegen Sie, wie Sie Spannung aufbauen und eine der folgenden Möglichkeiten nutzen können, indem Sie diese Erscheinungen mit Omen verbinden, nach denen die Charaktere suchen:

items: Flackernde Lichter entzünden sich in den einzelnen Augen der Schädel, die immer noch auf den Waffen montiert sind, und leuchten über den See hinaus.
Das Wasser des Sees verschmutzt sofort und wird rot vor Blut.
Das leise Murmeln orkischer Stimmen, die die Taten gefallener Helden preisen, weht durch die Luft.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: Die folgenden Orte sind auf Karte 6 vermerkt.

entries.name: 40. Overlook of Skulls
entries: Der Overlook of Skulls ist ein Ort der Ehre, an dem die Schädel der Helden der Vorfahren ausgestellt werden, damit man sich an sie erinnert.

Das sumpfige Ufer fällt zum See des Blutes ab (Gebiet 42). Eingebettet in den dicken Schlamm liegen verrostete Waffen, die mit Schädeln bedeckt sind und über das Wasser blicken. Eine gepanzerte Tür führt in die Heldengruft (Gebiet 41).

entries.name: Illumination
entries: Beide Seiten des Aussichtspunkts liegen in völliger Dunkelheit.

entries.name: Door
entries: Dicke Eisentüren, die mit Schmutz und Rost bedeckt sind, führen zum Gewölbe der Helden (Gebiet 41). Jede Tür ist verschlossen und durch einen {@spell arcane lock}-Zauber geschützt (in den DCs unten enthalten). Sie können mit einem erfolgreichen DC 25 Geschicklichkeits-Check mit {@item thieves' tools|PHB} geöffnet oder mit einem erfolgreichen DC 30 Stärke-Check niedergeschlagen werden.

entries.name: Muck
entries: Das Ufer ist mit einem übelriechenden, schwarzen Schlamm bedeckt, der den Stiefel festhält und jeden verlangsamt, der versucht, sich weniger als fünf Fuß vom Ufer entfernt zu bewegen. Ein erfolgreicher DC-12-Weisheitstest ({@skill Perception}) beim Durchsuchen des Schlamms zeigt, dass Hunderte von Orkknochen direkt unter der Oberfläche liegen; die Körper vieler geehrter Toter. Einer der Schädel, der von Vrograg Brokentusk, wacht gelegentlich noch auf, wenn er dazu aufgefordert wird.

entries.name: Skulls
entries: Dutzende von Orkschädeln thronen auf stark verrosteten Waffen, und viele weitere sind halb im Schlamm vergraben, wo die Waffen dem Alter zum Opfer gefallen sind. Bei jedem Schädel ist der Nasenrücken herausgebrochen. Ein erfolgreicher DC 10 Intelligenz ({@skill Religion}) erkennt, dass dies ein Brauch ist, um diejenigen zu ehren, die einen "guten Tod" im Kampf gestorben sind.

entries.name: The Skull of Vrograg Brokentusk
entries: Vrograg Brokentusk war ein Mitglied des Fang Trusts, der im Kampf gegen die verhassten Elfen heldenhaft starb. Ein Hauch von ihm bleibt in seinem Schädel, und wenn ein Charakter ihm sein Blut opfert, erwacht er mit einem gähnenden Stöhnen, wie ein alter Mann, der von einem langen Nickerchen aufsteht.

entries.name: Curmudgeon
entries: Vrograg ist ein verschrobener Typ, der immer das Schlimmste erwartet. Jedes Omen ist ein schlechtes, und die Chancen auf einen guten Tod sind gering. Er geht davon aus, dass die Figuren dem Untergang geweiht sind, genau wie der Rest der Stadt, und er hat nicht viel Zeit für Kinder, die in der Asche verlorener Größe spielen. Nur junge Orks seines eigenen Clans können ihn dazu bewegen, sein Wissen mit ihnen zu teilen, und selbst dann tut er es mit Traurigkeit, als würde er ihnen nur helfen, ihren Untergang hinauszuzögern.

entries.name: Stories of Yore
entries: Vrograg kennt den größten Teil der Geschichte der Stadt bis etwa 150 Jahre vor der Katastrophe, kann sich aber seltsamerweise nicht an ihren Namen erinnern. Wenn die Charaktere ihn für sich gewinnen, beantwortet er ihre Fragen nicht wirklich, sondern erzählt ihnen epische Geschichten, die jeweils mehrere Minuten dauern. Besonders gern erzählt er Geschichten von heldenhaften Kriegern. Vrograg ist ein bequemes Vehikel für den Spielleiter, um ein Stück verpasste Geschichte zu vermitteln oder einen Aufhänger für die Handlung zu schaffen, der zu einem anderen Bereich der Stadt führt.

entries.name: The Good Death
entries: Orks, die einen "guten Tod" sterben, werden von den Priestern von Yurtrus nach Gruumsh geschickt. Die Priester suchen die Leichen solcher gefallener Helden auf, schneiden ihnen die Köpfe ab, kochen oder räuchern sie, um den größten Teil des Fleisches zu entfernen, und brechen dann mit einem rituellen Schlag den Nasenrücken heraus, so dass der Schädel nur noch ein Auge hat. Orks, die die Stärke und Grausamkeit eines Feindes zu schätzen wissen, könnten sich dazu entschließen, diesen Feind zu ehren, indem sie ihm die gleiche Behandlung zukommen lassen. Die Körper von Orks, die in einer gescheiterten Schlacht sterben, werden zurückgelassen; sie waren schwach und verdienen es nicht, sich Gruumsh anzuschließen. Diejenigen, die an Altersschwäche sterben, werden in der Regel in den Schoß von Yurtrus aufgenommen, und ihre Knochen werden zum Bau von Einrichtungsgegenständen und Strukturen in Gebieten verwendet, die der Anbetung von Yurtrus gewidmet sind.

entries.name: 41. The Heroes' Vault
entries: Dieser Raum ist die letzte Ruhestätte der größten Helden der Stadt. Im Gegensatz zum Overlook ist die Gruft im Laufe der Zeit relativ trocken geblieben. Jeder, der dumm genug ist, seine Vorfahren zu bestehlen, wird die {@trap death fog trap|RtG} erleiden. Die Wände dieser Kammer sind mit Nischen bedeckt, die mit Knochen und Trophäen der Vergangenheit gefüllt sind.

entries.name: Illumination
entries: Im Tresorraum gibt es kein Licht.

entries.name: Burial Niches
entries: Es gibt Dutzende von Nischen, jede mit ein paar Knochen und einer Trophäe oder einem Schmuckstück. Die Schmuckstücke sind nicht von finanziellem Wert, sondern eher von kulturellem. Die meisten haben sich dem Zahn der Zeit ergeben und sind kaum mehr als Fragmente oder Staub, aber Stücke von Knochen, Stein oder Metall sind immer vorhanden. In mehreren Nischen sind Namen eingraviert, darunter: Ishi, der Hörer, Laylia, die Geisterwandlerin, Alloh, der Heiler, Gatalah, der Fährtenleser der Lieder, und Romdar, der Junge, der mit Blitzen spricht.

entries.name: Magic-Dampening Field
entries: Der gesamte Raum ist von einem Feld bedeckt, das dem Effekt der falschen Aura von Nystuls magischer Aura ähnelt. Alle Zauber und magischen Gegenstände erscheinen für Effekte, die Magie erkennen, als nicht-magisch.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In einer Nische, die Overlox Curgain Bloodsplatter gehört, sitzt ein Schädel, der rituell gebrochen wurde, um ein "Auge" zu haben, auf einem gefiederten Speer mit einer breiten schwarzen Metallklinge, die mit Runen versehen ist, die sie als Geldak, den Throatseeker, bezeichnen. Geldak ist ein bösartiger Speer, der warm wird, wenn er sich in einem Umkreis von 120 Fuß um einen Elfen befindet.
Zusätzlich zu Geldak kann aus den Gräbern Schmuck im Wert von 20 Gp erbeutet werden.

entries.name: 42. Lake of Blood
entries: Der See des Blutes ist die letzte Ruhestätte der Orks in der Stadt. Vier {@creature water weird||water weirds} bewachen den See, die vor langer Zeit beschworen wurden, um zu verhindern, dass jemand die Überreste der Toten stört. Sie greifen jeden an, der im See schwimmt, und reagieren außerdem innerhalb von zwei Runden auf den Ruf der Blauen Dame, wenn sie sie geistig herbeiruft.

Trotz seines Namens ist der See des Blutes nur mit Wasser gefüllt, das aus einer unterirdischen Quelle fließt. Durch die ständige Bewegung des Wassers wird der Schlamm aufgewirbelt, so dass das Wasser trübe ist, auch wenn man es bei Licht sehen kann.

entries.name: Illumination
entries: Die Höhle ist völlig dunkel.

entries.name: Lake
entries: Der Grund des Sees ist uneben und fällt bis zu einer Tiefe von 40 bis 60 Fuß ab. Der Boden des Sees ist mit demselben schwarzen Schlamm bedeckt wie das Ufer, und er ist ebenfalls mit den Knochen von jahrhundertealten orkischen Toten übersät. Das Wasser ist trüb, so dass es innerhalb von 10 Fuß leicht und darüber hinaus stark verdunkelt ist.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Der Seegrund ist mit den Knochen der Toten bedeckt, von denen einige ihre Wertsachen mitgenommen haben. Ein Charakter, der zehn Minuten damit verbringt, den Seegrund zu durchsuchen und eine DC 15 Weisheitsprüfung ({@skill Perception}) besteht, findet eine wasserdichte silberne Schatulle im Wert von 50 Goldstücken, die eine Halskette aus Wolfszähnen und Quarzstücken im Wert von 10 Goldstücken enthält, sowie eine {@item potion of greater healing}.

entries.name: 43. Final Rest of the Blue Lady
entries: Der letzte von Yurtrus' Getreuen wacht von diesem kalten Lagerplatz aus über die geehrten Toten. Ihr Name ist vergessen, die Blaue Dame ({@creature ghost}) wacht von der ätherischen Dimension aus. Wenn die Charaktere den Toten einfach nur ihre Aufwartung machen, lässt sie sie in Ruhe. Wenn sie versuchen, die Heldengruft zu rauben oder die Toten auf andere Weise zu entweihen, erscheint sie als traurig dreinblickende Orkfrau in blauen Gewändern, die am Lagerfeuer sitzt. Sie winkt die Charaktere zu sich, spricht aber nicht.

Wenn die Charaktere sie angreifen oder ihre Blasphemie fortsetzen, winkt sie mit der Hand und aus dem Schlamm um sie herum erheben sich drei {@creature flying sword||flying swords} und zwei {@creature earth elemental||earth elementals} aus dem schwarzen Schlamm und den Knochen der Toten. Diejenigen, die die Toten entweihen, werden von ihr keine Gnade erfahren.

Bei näherer Betrachtung ist der schlammige Lagerplatz mit weggeworfenen Waffen und den Knochen von Orks übersät. Ein verrotteter Schlafsack liegt neben einer mit Holz gefüllten Feuerstelle und wartet darauf, angezündet zu werden.

entries.name: Illumination
entries: Wenn die Blaue Dame es wünscht, kann das Lagerfeuer angezündet werden, das Licht, aber keine Wärme abgibt. Ansonsten ist dieser Bereich dunkel.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Die Geheimtür im Nordwesten kann mit einer erfolgreichen DC 15 Weisheit ({@skill Perception}) Prüfung gefunden werden. Sie ist nicht verschlossen und führt zum Gebiet 60.

entries.name: Rotting Root
entries: Kurz vor dem Untergang beanspruchte {@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG}, ein zwergischer Druide, dieses Gebiet als seine Heimat. Bei einem Ausflug ins Underdark stieß er auf einen seltsamen, intelligenten Pilz, der ihm ein Angebot machte, das er nicht ablehnen konnte. Der Druide wurde von den Sporen des Pilzes infiziert, kehrte nach Hause zurück und ist seither hier zu Hause. Die einzige Gesellschaft, die er hat, sind die befallenen Überreste der gelegentlichen Eindringlinge - Faultiere.

entries.name: Rotting Root Clan Omens
entries: Der Rotting Root Clan vernichtet Korruption und Bosheit, wenn sie in der Natur auftauchen. Entgleisungen und Monstrositäten, die ihre Umgebung verderben würden, gehören zu ihren Hauptfeinden.

items: Nur eine reinigende Flamme kann ein verpestetes Herz wegbrennen.
Ein Baum, der in blutige Erde gepflanzt wird, verrottet von innen heraus.
Wenn tausend Augen auf dich gerichtet sind, musst du tausend Augen ausstechen, wenn du ungesehen bleiben willst.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: Wenn nicht anders angegeben, weist das Gebiet diese Merkmale auf:

entries.name: Dimensions and Terrain
entries: Die Wände und Böden sind eben und aus behauenen Steinen gemauert, die Decken sind 10 Fuß hoch. Unter den Füßen befindet sich ein dichtes Myzelgewächs. Große Büschel hochgewachsener Pilze wachsen im gesamten Bereich. Die Wände sind mit verschlungenen, ungewöhnlichen Symbolen, spiralförmigen Kreisen, gezackten Winkeln und scheinbar unsinnigen Bildern bedeckt, die alle mit einer unaussprechlichen braunen Substanz bemalt worden sind.

entries.name: Light
entries: Der Raum ist völlig dunkel, abgesehen von gelegentlichen Flecken biolumineszierender Pilze, die in einem Radius von 1,5 Metern ein schwaches Licht verbreiten.

entries.name: Sounds and Smells
entries: Keuchender Atem, schlurfende Füße. Fäulnis, Staub und frisch aufgewühlte Erde.

entries.name: Mycelium
entries: Though dense enough to walk on in most parts, occasional 5-foot patches of the undergrowth are loose and are {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Mushrooms
entries: The mushrooms vary in size from a few inches to 5 feet in height, and they can be found in dozens of vibrant shades of red, blue, green, and yellow. Any of the area's denizens ({@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG} or the rotters) can meld into a clump of mushrooms and move to another within 100 feet as if using the Tree Stride ability. A clump of mushrooms occupies a 5-foot square (AC 11, 28 hit points, and immunity to poison damage).

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 7.

entries.name: 44. A Warning
entries: The mycelium grows only in thin patches here, leaving most of the stone floor visible. A copse of mushrooms stands in the southeastern corner. The only other feature is the orc skeleton wearing rags and a small satchel—all of which are covered in a light dusting of what looks like spores.

Characters who inspect the skeleton or the satchel it carries risk disturbing the fungus covering its body. Upon opening the satchel, spores fill a 5-foot area immediately surrounding the skeleton. Any living creature in the area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature has vulnerability to necrotic and poison damage, and has disadvantage on saving throws against poison. The satchel contains three tarnished silver coins and an empty vial.

entries.name: 45. Storeroom
entries: Moldering remains of crates, barrels, and other containers lay scattered about, their contents spoiled beyond recognition. A {@creature rotter|RtG} (see appendix A) is here, rotting.

entries.name: Locked Door
entries: The wooden door on the eastern wall is locked. The fungus colony doesn't understand the concept behind a key, but it has no need to unlock it anyway. The door can be unlocked with a successful DC 17 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|PHB}. However, the door is so swollen with moisture that opening it still requires a successful DC 17 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: 46. Hallway
entries: This short hallway features the other entrance to the area. The mycelium here has grown up the door and walls—effectively blocking egress. A creature attempting to open the door must succeed on a DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to brush the growth aside. However, doing so fills the entire hallway with spores (see area 44, above).

entries.name: 47. Laboratory
entries: This area was once a place of study and experimentation for {@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG}. It has seen better days. Two {@creature rotter|RtG|rotters} (see appendix A) can usually be found here, though there is a {@chance 25|25 percent} chance that they've wandered into area 48, below. The niche in the northern wall houses a wide, shallow font that trickles with fresh water. A copse of mushrooms grows just east of the font.

entries.name: 48. Grim Nutriment
entries: A collected mass of skeletons—orcish from the look of it—hang from the wide, square column in the eastern portion of the room, held in place by the thick growth of spongy tentacles woven through their bones. Closer examination reveals the bones are covered in symbols similar to those painted onto the walls.
A handful of slender pink mushrooms grow in and around the skeletons. Three copses of mushrooms are scattered around the room.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A total of three pink mushrooms can be harvested from the pillar, each of which functions as a {@item potion of greater healing} that also provides enough nourishment to sustain a creature for one day. However, the mushrooms are delicate, and each requires a successful DC 13 Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check to pick.

entries.name: 49. Fetid Oracle
entries: This room is a veritable jungle of tall mushrooms of various colors and shapes. While it's obscured by the growth, the glow of a campfire can be seen reflecting off the walls and ceiling north of the entrance. Three copses of mushrooms are spread throughout the room. The mushrooms in the northern portion of the room have been cleared away. Two benches made of alchemically treated mushrooms are placed around a central fire. {@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG} (see appendix A) sits on a bench, staring into the flames.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG} carries 50 gp worth of coins of various mints as well as a +2 rod of the pact keeper.

entries.name: 49a. Reliquary
entries: The door to this room is made of precisely hewn stone. It's locked and trapped with a 5th-level glyph of warding that is triggered by any nonplant creature attempting to open the door. Detecting the nearly {@condition invisible} glyph requires a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. However, the check is made with disadvantage due to the mycelium growth on the wall. If triggered, the glyph casts {@spell cloudkill} (save DC 15).

entries.name: Dirt-Under-Nails
entries: While he may have once been a dwarf, {@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG} is now anything but. The fungus's hold is apparent; his mottled skin is various shades of brown, purple, and white, and his beard is a network of pale, wispy roots. A trio of bracket fungi grow along his neck and twist around to the back of his head. His eyes are cloudy and when he speaks, his voice is raspy. He refers to himself as "we" and "us," likely referring to the spores that have taken root in his body.

{@creature Dirt-Under-Nails|RtG} is eternally patient, the only thing that can truly rouse his anger is a threat to himself or those he shares company with. He's perfectly content to be left to stare into his fire for eternity.

entries.name: Red Wardens
entries: This cavernous area was once a subterranean garden that served as a font of flora used for both medicinal and dietary needs. It was also a gathering site for ceremonies to honor or celebrate important developments shared between the tribes, such as advancements for the city or victories shared between tribal leaders. The area was overseen by the Red Wardens.
The Red Falls gets its name from the stream that flows through the area. The rocky sediment along the bottom of the stream, combined with the light from above, gives the water a reddish hue.

entries.name: Red Wardens Omens
entries: This subtribe's traditions closely follow those of Luthic, the Cave Mother. They promoted unity among the people by enforcing the traditions and rituals centered around the circle of life and death. They were often warrior-shamans and healers.
Red Wardens have their own unique customs guided by specific omens and prophecies:

items: The shared blood of orcs brings life to the hearth and death to its enemies.
To carry fear when gazing upon your own reflection is to invite death into your soul.
You must cast a shadow at least once each day to expel the corruption within you.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: Each section in this area shares the following features:

entries.name: Terrain
entries: The ground is covered in a mixture of dirt and thick, mossy overgrowth.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: Three fissures in the ceiling, no more than two feet wide, give way to periodic breaches of sunlight and moonlight within the area. The rest of the ceiling is covered with a bioluminescent moss that emits a soft, reddish-orange glow. Even together, both of these provide only a dim light source.

entries.name: Underground Stream
entries: Water flows from the south into a stream that divides the area, then down through the portcullis gate in the northeast into the Lake of Ancestors. The water on the south side of the chamber is four feet deep and is six feet deep on the north side after falling into the small pool (area 50). The bioluminescent moss that grows on the ceiling also grows along the ground beneath the stream's surface, giving the water a distinct reddish hue.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 8.

entries.name: 50. Chamber of the Mother
entries: This chamber was once the site of many tribal gatherings and processions of honor. It also served as grounds for harvesting flora for food and medicine.
The rushing stream drops off of a steep ledge into a small pool on the north side of the chamber. A shaft of light shines down upon the waters from a crack in the ceiling above.
The waterfall drops ten feet into a small pool of glowing red water. The pool is seven feet deep.

entries.name: The Last Warden
entries: The spirit of Ahthi Greenclaws, last of the Red Wardens, resides here, appearing only when the ritual is performed at the Heroes' Bridge (area 51).

entries.name: 50a. Warden's Gate

entries: A rusty iron portcullis blocks passage to the northeast. Alongside the passage beyond the gate, water flows from a stream that cuts through the area. The stream bears a distinct reddish color which steadily fades once it reaches the portcullis.
The gate itself is rusted and worn. There are several options available for getting past it.

entries.name: Using the Crank
entries: A crank on the nearby wall on either side of the gate can be used to open it, which requires a successful DC 14 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. This method requires some finesse. The portcullis opens only halfway (about 4 feet) and must be held open, but too much force causes the rusty hoisting mechanism to break. Each round, the character holding the portcullis open must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the chains snap and the portcullis slams shut. Each character moving beneath the portcullis must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) piercing damage.

Forcing it Open. A character can bend the bars with a successful DC 19 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, creating a gap wide enough for a Medium or smaller creature to fit through. If all else fails, an opening of the same size can be made by damaging the rusted beams. A weak section of the portcullis has AC 13, 45 hit points, and resistance to piercing damage.

entries.name: 50b. Statue and Grounds
entries: This corner of the chamber has stairs leading up to the south and a door leading to the north. Next to the stairs, a stone statue of a cave bear stands on a large circular platform.

entries.name: Statue of the Mother
entries: The cave bear statue has abnormally long, sharp talons, identifying it as a representation of the goddess Luthic. A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals the arms of the statue can be raised upward. Doing so causes the entire platform to slide to the north, revealing a 10-foot drop beneath it into a hidden passage to area 66.

entries.name: Poisonous Patch
entries: The patch of fungus next to the stream is poisonous when disturbed. It can be spotted and identified with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. When a creature moves at least 5 feet into this patch, it releases a cloud of poisonous spores. The creature and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned}. A {@condition poisoned} character can repeat this saving throw once every hour, removing the effect upon a success.

entries.name: 50c. Overgrown Flora
entries: This corner of the chamber is where most of the medicinal herbs were grown and harvested. A {@creature cloaker} has made its home on the ceiling of this area alongside four {@creature giant bat||giant bats}. The cloaker attacks any characters that move into this side of the chamber.

entries.name: Entangling Vines
entries: The vegetation in this area has been corrupted by foul magics, writhing along the ground and wrapping about the legs of creatures passing through them. The ground here counts as {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. Characters moving through this area must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone} at the end of their move. Characters who run or take the {@action Dash} action have disadvantage on the roll.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check identifies particular mosses and herbs with healing properties. If gathered and processed with an {@item herbalism kit|PHB} for one hour, there is enough to produce two antitoxins and two potions of healing.

entries.name: 51. Warden's Terrace

entries: Towering fungi grow out from the moss-covered floor, reaching almost as high as the ceiling. A stone bridge provides passage across the stream.

A {@creature rot troll|MTF} (see appendix A) has made its lair here. It resides on the platform at the top of the western staircase and attacks the party on sight. The stairs on either side of the chamber both end in walls of collapsed debris. This troll can make one additional claw attack with its Multiattack action.

entries.name: Rushing Current
entries: The current in this part of the chamber is strong, rushing in from an opening to the south. The water here is seven feet deep. Characters who fall into the water must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be carried along with the current at a rate of 20 feet per round. Characters pushed into the rocks take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Heroes' Bridge
entries: The bridge is decorated with the carved names of heroes and leaders who have been honored within this chamber. Characters who perform the blood bond ritual (see area 54) here, each take 1 slashing damage. The ritual summons the spirit of Ahthi Greenclaws.

The spirit rises from the small pool in area 50 and cleanses the area. Once cleansed, the poisonous patch in area 50b and the entangling vines in area 50c are both eradicated. If instead the blood of any other creature is intentionally spilled into the pool, Ahthi Greenclaws transforms into an empowered {@creature water elemental}. The elemental can make one additional slam attack with its Multiattack action.

entries.name: 52. Workshops
entries: Each of these rooms contain a variety of crafting materials. Most of the tools are ruined. If the party spends at least five minutes searching and make a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, they find an {@item herbalism kit|PHB}, a set of {@item mason's tools|PHB}, and a set of {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}.

entries.name: 53. Painted Hall
entries: The walls of this room are covered in paintings and stone carvings that depict and describe several significant events that mark the development and growth of the city and its tribal society. Characters who make a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check glean some historical information (such as the city's name and how its peoples came to rise under the guidance of their deities).

entries.name: 54. Ritual Chamber
entries: This smaller room is dressed in faded painted banners depicting the different rituals practiced by the tribe for major events such as honoring war heroes, treaties, and changes in tribal leadership.

entries.name: Blood Bond Ritual
entries: A successful DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check identifies the Heroes' Bridge in area 51, as well as the ritual performed between prominent tribe members. It involves one or more orcs cutting their palms and squeezing their blood simultaneously into the running waters.

entries.name: Water Font
entries: A four-foot-tall cylindrical container sits against the north wall, filled with dirty, viscous water. If cleansed with purify food and drink, or if the blood bond ritual is performed at the bridge in area 51, the water is clear. Once per day, if a character stares into the font's clear waters and makes a successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, they gain the benefit of a {@spell scrying} spell.

items: When handling the honored dead, show respect by blinding yourself, or your dishonor will taint their spirit.
When offering another a drink, prove your honorable intentions by taking the first sip.
Drawing blood with malice in a place of healing will curse you and your line forever.
If you turn away an injured orc, you doom yourself to suffer their injuries.
The waters of home are the strongest cure for any ailing orc.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 9.

entries.name: 55. Shrine to Luthic
entries: A small shrine to Luthic, the orc goddess of medicine, still stands, though any cloth or other soft materials have long ago rotted off its stone. Atop a high slab, a carved statue depicts a female orc wearing druidic talismans and standing above several wounded orc soldiers, with her arms outstretched. An inscription, shallowed by dust and age, reads "With renewed life, pursue thy quarry."

The shrine is as old as its surroundings, but still has some magic infusing it. If an orc prays at the shrine, they have advantage on their next three Constitution saving throws. This benefit lasts until the next time they finish a long rest.

entries.name: 56. Healing Floor
entries: This long, rectangular room is scattered with the debris of rotted furniture and piles of degraded cloth. A few stone slabs remain intact among the detritus, each of a size and height to function as beds for orc residents. One slab still holds the remains of an orc; now just bones and scraps of metal armor.
Set into the north and south walls are deep alcoves, three on either side. In the northeast alcove, you see movement, though it floats just at the edge of your vision.

In the northeast alcove is Hinsha, an orc {@creature ghost}. Hinsha was the lead healer of this area when she was alive, and continued to haunt the area after her untimely death. When the players first approach, she is scared and seems about to lash out at them. When she sees that they're orcs, she relaxes, and thanks Luthic that they're here. She has the following information to give:

items: Years ago, members of the ruling clan abruptly abdicated their position, throwing the city into chaos.
A terrible civil war ensued throughout the city, with members of the different family-tribes fighting for power.
Hinsha's ward was a firm place of no fighting where any orc could seek asylum and healing.
Eventually, the Boneshield clan grew impatient with Hinsha's refusal to hand over injured enemies.
The Boneshields launched an assault on the ward, and Hinsha's staff were ill-equipped to handle the full fighting force. She and her staff were slaughtered, along with her patients.
Survivors of the war recognized that the city was no longer safe, so, clan by clan, they left to establish new homes.

entries: When the players inform Hinsha of their intent to reunite the clans and reestablish the keep, she is cautiously optimistic. "This was the beating heart of our people," she explains, "and you need to cleanse it."
Hinsha says she can perform a ritual which will ward off the ill will and betrayal that taints the place. However, she'll need three ritual components to do so:

items: The still-beating heart of a foe thrice slain (found in area 57).
The purest waters sourced from our home (found in area 60).
A poultice made from the bones of the honorable dead (found in area 59).

entries.name: The Ritual
entries: Once the players return to Hinsha with the items for the ritual, she asks that they help her put the final spirits to rest.
As she performs the ceremony, three waves of spirits assault the players. The next wave arrives as soon as the previous wave is destroyed:

items: {@creature Poltergeist||Poltergeists} (one for each player)
{@creature Ghost||Ghosts} (one for every two players) and two specters
Two {@creature wraith||wraiths}

entries: The poltergeists generally avoid getting too near the players, instead using their Telekinetic Thrust to hurl various bits of debris at the party. However, due to the 12-foothigh ceilings, they can never get high enough to be out of melee range.
As soon as the last enemy is defeated, read:

With a sudden rise in volume, Hinsha utters the last of her incantations, and the reagents in front of her flash a bright green. They melt, hovering in the air, and coalesce into a smooth sphere which shifts through several colors before settling a bright red. Warm light pulses from it at the same steady beat as the terrible heart.

The pace quickens, and the light seems to coat everything in the room. "Thank you," Hinsha says solemnly from behind the sphere. "Perhaps you are the change needed in this dark place. You must promise to never again allow greed to consume us all."
When the players assent to this, Hinsha and the sphere fade to nothingness. The area feels better, as if an intangible evil has finally been dispelled.

entries.name: 57. Quarantine
entries: The door to this chamber is festooned with warding runes and clear, strongly worded warnings in Orc. They read "An evil contained; death to those that enter" and "Twice killed, the heart still beats." Though the magic has lessened over time, the runes still glow faintly.
It isn't hard to open the door from outside, and as soon as a player does, read:
As the slightest crack forms between the door and its jamb, the door bursts open, and a rush of unbelievably strong wind pushes all of you back into the main healing room.

As you get back on your feet, you see a new figure in the room, and he looks decidedly upset. He is roughly humanoid, though easily nine feet tall. He once sported a pair of impressive horns and wings, but all that remains are the tattered remains where they were violently torn from him. His chest, latticed with deep scars, thumps audibly with a slow, steady heartbeat.
This is a {@creature horned devil} which immediately attacks. Once defeated, its body rapidly disintegrates to ash, leaving behind the beating heart.

entries.name: 58. Intake
entries: This room is dominated by a long stone slab which was clearly a desk or table of some kind. On the northern wall, a carved relief of the goddess Luthic looks down on the room with a matronly gaze.
An inscription beneath the relief reads, "No injury too great, no need too strong."

The room has some scattered debris from broken furniture, and the door to the northwest is closed, but not locked. If the players investigate, they find a rotted box beneath the desk containing a {@item potion of greater healing} and a {@item potion of healing}.
Taking the potions angers the two {@creature ghost||ghosts} invisibly skulking around the room. They attack the intruders.

entries.name: 59. Staff Sleeping Quarters

entries: This room contains the scattered remains of several bunkbeds and other furniture. As you enter, movement stirs in the piles of detritus, and the bones of a dozen orc skeletons rise to face you.
There are twelve {@creature skeleton||skeletons} in here with the following modifications:

items: They have the Aggressive and Undead Fortitude traits.
They have a Strength score of 16.
They carry greataxes with a +5 to hit which deal 9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

entries: These skeletons are the remains of the healing ward's staff, though now they are mindless undead. Once defeated, the players are able to grind a few of the bones into a usable poultice. However, because of the tribe's superstition, this must be done while blindfolded or the poultice won't be an effective reagent. Hinsha can explain this to the players if needed.

entries.name: 60. Storage
entries: In this room, medical supplies spill out of rotting boxes. In one corner, the contents of a shattered vial have eaten a small crater into the stone floor.
As you enter, one of the intact vials from a crate wobbles, then flies through the air to shatter on the wall next to you.

The four {@creature poltergeist||poltergeists} in the room attempt to fling vials of acid at the players. There are twelve vials in the box, and the acid eats into the floor where it is thrown, even if it hits a creature.

If a vial hits a square or a creature in a square over the secret door, it is revealed to be a former well that has been cleverly hidden to look like part of the floor. A ladder descends to area 43 in the caverns below.

Once the players defeat the poltergeists, they can take any remaining vials. Additionally, there is a {@item potion of greater healing} and a {@item potion of diminution}, neither of which are labeled.

There is also a large flask of clear water stoppered with wax. This is a reagent for Hinsha's ceremony. As befitting an honorable orc, a player must unstopper and taste the water prior to giving it to her (an ancient custom to prove one isn't offering a {@condition poisoned} drink).

entries.name: 61. Cavern
entries: Upon entering the cavern, the stream's flow widens to the trickle of a shallow pool before narrowing again on the other side. Several boulders lie scattered around the chamber, though the floor looks remarkably smooth and bare between them.

Two {@creature galeb duhr} hide among the boulders, making the most of their False Appearance and {@sense tremorsense}. Once the party is entirely within the chamber, they spring an attack. The galeb duhr can't be identified except by magical means, so the players will likely be surprised during the first round of combat.

entries.name: Fang Trust
entries: A community of orcs known as the Fang Trust looked after the city's worgs. A character who belongs to the Fang Trust knows the group believes that offering a worg a meal upon first meeting it was the quickest way to bond with the creature.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: The orcs trained and cared for worgs in this part of the city. Worgs were guardians, mounts, trackers, and friends to the orcs. All areas of the worg ground have the following features:

items: The ceilings are 15 feet high.
There are no light sources.
The walls and doors are made of stone. The doors have no knobs or handles but are made to be easily pushed open from either direction.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 10.

entries.name: 62. Monument Chamber
entries: This dusty stone chamber has Orc carved on the walls from floor to ceiling; most of it faded beyond legibility. The few readable words are the names of worgs that died serving the city. Translated from Orc, these names are Drool Puppy, Great Claw, Howler, Quiet Step, and Snoof.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that the readable names radiate auras of illusion magic. If a creature touches one of these names, the sound of the deceased worg's unique howl fills the chamber for a moment before fading away.

entries.name: 63. Trainers' Chambers
entries: Four stone bunks are built into the walls of this dusty chamber and the Fang Trust's symbol, a circle of six fangs, is carved into the floor.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature crawling claw} made from an orc's hand hides in one of the bunks. The claw attempts to remain hidden, fleeing if attacked or obviously noticed, skittering through the city to get away from potential aggressors. A creature with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notices the claw.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The crawling claw wears a ring of animal friendship.

entries.name: 64. Funeral Room
entries: Ancient soot and black burn marks mar the floor of this chamber, which sports a 3-foot-diameter hole in the ceiling. This room was used to burn the corpses of deceased worgs.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If a creature crosses the center of this room, the ghost of a worg named Great Claw appears. She has the statistics of a {@creature ghost} with the following adjustments:

items: Great Claw is Large and has 55 ({@dice 10d10}) hit points.
Great Claw speaks Common and Orc.

entries: When she first appears, Great Claw snarls at the characters, warning them to leave. A successful DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check convinces Great Claw the characters mean no harm. A character who puts out an offering of food for Great Claw gains advantage on this check, for even though she can't eat the food, she appreciates the gesture. If the characters refuse to leave and fail this check, she attacks, fighting until destroyed.
If the characters succeed on the check, Great Claw is overjoyed to see orcs have returned to restore the city. She shares the following information with the characters:

items: Great Claw was the leader of the worgs when the city fell.
Great Claw and other two worgs, Howler and Snoof, died in the city's final days. Because they were sworn to protect this place, their spirits haven't been able to journey on.

Many years ago, a necromancer searching the city for corpses twisted Howler and Snoof's spirits into evil {@creature wraith||wraiths}. They killed the necromancer and now stalk their old pens (area area 66).

If the characters destroy Howler and Snoof, the worgs' spirits will be laid to rest and Great Claw will reward them. If the characters have already done this, Great Claw can feel that her friends have moved on and rewards the characters.

entries.name: Great Claw's Reward
entries: If the characters kill the {@creature wraith||wraiths} in area 66, Great Claw touches them one by one. Each character gains a charm of heroism (see "Charms" in chapter 7 of the Dungeon Master's Guide).

entries.name: 65. Training Room
entries: The remains of three rusted iron dummies litter the floor of this chamber. A character who examines the dummies finds punctures in the metal. A successful DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check reveals these punctures were made by a worg's bite.

entries.name: 66. Worg Pens

entries: A cold chill blows through this chamber that smells faintly of sweaty, furry animal. In the center of the floor lies a black-cloaked skeleton. Six cozy pens littered with ancient chicken bones are built into the north, south, and east walls of the chamber.
When the characters enter this chamber, two worg wraiths appear and attack, fighting until destroyed. They have the statistics of {@creature wraith||wraiths} with the following adjustments:

items: They are Large and have 76 ({@dice 9d10 + 27}) hit points each.
They speak Common and Orc.

entries: The first time a character uses an action to offer the wraiths food, the wraiths use their next action attempting to eat the food. After one attempt, they remember they can't eat anything now they're undead and resume attacking.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The skeleton wears a belt pouch containing ruby dust worth 750 gp.

entries.name: Quill Keepers
entries: The Quill Keepers were the city's scholars who recorded histories and taught young citizens how to read and write. A Quill Keeper knows that the group places tomes containing the most dangerous knowledge on top of bookshelves, keeping those books furthest from the evil forces of the Lower Planes.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: The orcs created a place where they could study, write, teach, and read. This area of the city was simply called the Conservatory. All areas of the Conservatory have the following features:

items: The ceilings are 10 feet high.
There are no light sources.
The walls and doors are made of stone.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 10.

entries.name: 67. Study
entries: This room is littered with the rotting remains of broken wood tables and cushioned chairs. Empty bookshelves are built into the walls. A character who searches the top of the shelves and succeeds on a DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check finds a button that unlocks the door to area 69.

entries.name: 68. Closet
entries: This chamber holds a dozen moth-eaten robes embroidered with the Quill Keepers' symbol, a pair of crossed quills.

entries.name: 69. Scroll Vault
entries: The door to this room is locked, though no keyhole is apparent. A button in area 67 unlocks the door, or a successful DC 22 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check forces the door open. The door has AC 17, 27 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

A scroll case lies on the center of a rug woven with the Quill Keepers' symbol, a pair of crossed quills. This {@creature rug of smothering} attacks if the characters broke down or forced open the door, but otherwise it remains dormant.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The scroll case contains a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell modify memory}.

entries.name: 70. Librarian's Office

entries: This dusty office is still intact. An enormous stone desk dominates the west wall, a plush chair rotting behind it Along the north wall, a floor-to-ceiling bookshelf holds musty tomes.

Most of the books on the shelves are ruined due to age, but a character who takes 10 minutes to search the top shelf finds an intact journal authored by Scalora the Learned. The journal contains all the information found in the "Background" section of the introduction about the history of the city.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The outline of a secret door that connects this area to area 71 can be detected with a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

entries.name: 71. Library
entries: Bookshelves containing ruined tomes line the walls of this chamber. Torin Dwendale (chaotic evil male Tethyrian human {@creature mage}) searches the library with his {@creature shield guardian} for useful spellbooks but has found nothing so far. When he sees the characters, he introduces himself with a foppish flourish and tells them he is searching the ruins for spells to add to his collection.

If any of the characters carry a spellbook, a Book of Shadows, or a {@item spell scroll}, he attacks, hoping to steal the item. Torin fights until reduced to half his hit points, he gets the item he wants, or his shield guardian is destroyed, then flees. Otherwise, he tries to get the characters to battle the golems in area 72, tempting them with tales of treasure in the golem laboratory. He hopes the characters kill the golems or vice versa, then he can kill the weakened victor and claim the treasure in the room.
Torin cast a ward on his {@item shield guardian amulet|IDRotF} that makes it crumble to dust if it is removed from his body. His spellbook contains all the spells he has prepared.

entries.name: 72. Golem Laboratory

entries: Two creatures made of stitched-together flesh crash about this room covered in broken furniture and glass. All that remains intact is a single bookshelf with one tome atop its highest level.

The two {@creature flesh golem||flesh golems} in this chamber are out of control after centuries of being cooped up. They attack any other creatures they notice, fighting until destroyed. After the flesh golems are destroyed, Torin and his shield guardian (see area 71) seize the moment to attack the characters or steal the spellbook in this room.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: The only book on the shelf is a spellbook with the following spells: {@spell banishment}, {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell counterspell}, {@spell detect magic}, {@spell detect thoughts}, {@spell fire shield}, {@spell fly}, {@spell globe of invulnerability}, {@spell identify}, {@spell lightning bolt}, {@spell mage armor}, {@spell magic missile}, {@spell mind blank}, {@spell mirror image}, {@spell misty step}, {@spell scrying}, {@spell stoneskin}, {@spell teleport}, {@spell time stop}, and {@spell wall of force}.

entries.name: False Hope, Dark Promises
entries: As the characters enter this final area, they immediately come under the scrutiny of the {@creature balhannoth|MTF} (see appendix A) that's made its lair here. Native to the Shadowfell, the vicious, predatory balhannoth alters reality in its lair to make the place appear inviting to travelers. Once the orcs step inside, the balhannoth begins to weave its snare.

entries.name: Dungeon Features
entries: The balhannoth's lair has the following features:

entries.name: Illumination
entries: There is no light here, except where noted.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The ceilings are twenty feet high.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The doors are stone and quite heavy; over the years they have become stuck in their frames and require a successful DC 16 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to force open. They aren't locked.

entries.name: Dungeon Locations
entries: This dungeon area is keyed to map 11.

entries.name: 73. Balhannoth Lair
entries: All of the chambers throughout the area shown on map 11 are part of the balhannoth's lair. Thanks to a limited form of telepathy, the creature can sense the desires of others and identify images of places where they expect those desires to be met. The balhannoth then warps reality around it, remaking the environment so that it matches the appearance of the place the creature seeks.

A balhannoth thrives on fear and despair, taking pleasure in the horror its victims experience. It terrorizes its prey by using its reality-warping powers to mask its presence until it can snatch the target. Then it teleports away to feed on its victims.

entries.name: Preparatory Note
entries: As you're preparing to play this adventure, you'll want to ask each of the players about their characters hopes and dreams for this expedition. This is also a good time to ask players about lines and veils as well. It's important to avoid personal triggers in an encounter like this. If they're uncomfortable speaking of these things in front of the group, provide them with a note card or other private means to communicate these with you. This should occur before they even begin wandering around the dungeon, and it can happen as part of a ‘sending-off' ritual held by the elders that set them on this task.

Once the characters enter, it will be up to you to improvise the description of the areas as the balhannoth hunts them down and attempts to pick them off, one-by-one. If that weren't enough, there is a trio of gelatinous cubes wandering these halls, taking advantage of the confusion caused by the balhannoth to feed.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: Once the orcs have cleared out the entire dungeon and destroyed the balhannoth, their combined tribes celebrate them as heroes. The new Overlox will enlist them as a group to participate as part of a special council in rebuilding and protecting their home. The new Overlox will ask the characters to donate all but 20 percent of any nonmagical treasure they might have discovered to help resupply, but they allow them to keep any magic items found.
